This is in addition to the red stop button on the motor control panel.Moreover, because engine lathes are driven through reduction gearing, cutting current to the motor rapidly stops the rotation of the workpiece.My metal lathe is driven by a variable speed DC motor. However, if the lathe (metal or wood) were instead powered by an alternating current motor, there is another method to quickly bring it to a stop, an electronic safety device for AC motors called a Short Stop.This is made by the company Ambi Tech. The Short Stop is an electronic motor brake that stops the inertia of a running machine from allowing the machine to continue spinning after the current to the motor has been shut off.The Short Stop works by momentarily injecting DC current into the windings of an AC motor when the STOP button is pushed. This has the effect of turning the AC motor into a DC brake. This QUICKLY stops the turning of the motor and anything connected to it.I have an AmbiTech Short Stop motor control on my Powermatic 26 shaper.The intensity of the braking induced by the Short Stop is adjustable. This is necessary as too rapid a braking action on a machine that has a heavy cutter head attached to the spindle by a nut can actually cause the fastening nut to unscrew.Note that each of these safety devices only stops the motor AFTER someone has pushed the STOP switch. This differs from the stopping device on a SawStop which drops a sacrificial block of lead into the teeth of the saw blade stopping it (and destroying the lead bloc and usually ruining the saw blade) when the device senses the slight electrical contact of a finger with the saw blade.The SawStop technology could not be used with either a metal or wood lathe as there is in operation of either continual contact between the workpiece and the cutting tool and the operator.
